docs.lead_paragraph: One in four women ages 14 to 59 is infected with HPV, the sexually transmitted virus that in some forms can cause cervical cancer, according to the first broad national estimate.

headline.main: Study Tracks Rate of Cervical Cancer Virus
headline.print_headline: Study Tracks Rate of Cervical Cancer Virus

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''A Necessary Vaccine'' (editorial, Feb. 26): Government-mandated vaccination programs may be appropriate when facing a clear public health crisis and where the long-term risks and benefits of the prevention measure are known.

headline.main: The Costs and Risks of a Vaccine

docs.abstract: Six letters comment on Feb 26 editorial on mandatory vaccinations for young women against cervical cancer; Barkley Calkins says incidence of cervical cancer and genital warts does not approach level of public health threat to warrant government-mandated vaccinations; Dr David Alter holds that mandatory requirements for vaccine is sign that society perceives good parenting to be failing; Dr Barbara Gold says cost of vaccine for family practitioners is deterrent to stocking it; Dr Joseph More says if goal is to sharply reduce risk of cervival cancer, vaccine should also be promoted for boys; Rose D Sigman says mandating young girls as guinea pigs is reckless; Dr Henry Greenspan says controversy surrounding vaccine reflects general erosion of trust in pharmaceutical industry
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''A Necessary Vaccine'' (editorial, Feb. 26):      Government-mandated vaccination programs may be appropriate when facing a clear public health crisis and where the long-term risks and benefits of the prevention measure are...

headline.seo: Male Biological Clock - It Seems the Fertility Clock Ticks for Men, Too - Health News
headline.main: It Seems the Fertility Clock Ticks for Men, Too
headline.print_headline: It Seems the Fertility Clock Ticks for Men, Too

docs.snippet: Mounting evidence is suggesting that as men get older, they face an increased risk of fathering children with abnormalities.

docs.lead_paragraph: Black women have significantly higher rates of premature birth than white women, and a new study suggests there may be underlying genetic factors even when other known risks are taken into account. The researchers, who published their findings this month in The American Journal of Obstetrics & Gynecology, say that even though preterm birth is not a desirable outcome, it may provide some advantage, perhaps protection against diseases -- in somewhat the same way the gene for sickle cell confers protection against malaria.

headline.main: Study Points to Genetics in Disparities in Preterm Births

docs.abstract: Drs Louis J Muglia and F Sessions Cole, Washington University pediatrics professors, lead study on premature births that suggests genetics may play part in baby being born early; emphasize that while there is likely genetic component, other risk factors, like family history and environment, play part in pre-term birth; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Black women have significantly higher rates of premature birth than white women, and a new study suggests there may be underlying genetic factors even when other known risks are taken into account.     The researchers, who published their findings...

docs.lead_paragraph: When it comes to fertility and the prospect of having normal babies, it has always been assumed that men have no biological clock -- that unlike women, they can have it all, at any age. But mounting evidence is raising questions about that assumption, suggesting that as men get older, they face an increased risk of fathering children with abnormalities. Several recent studies are starting to persuade many doctors that men should not be too cavalier about postponing marriage and children.

headline.main: It Seems the Fertility Clock Ticks for Men, Too

docs.abstract: Research into male fertility suggests that not only women should be concerned about their age and how it may affect pregnancy, but older men are also at increased risk of having child with birth defects; although impact is largely unknown, researchers suggest that men follow healthy lifestyle if they expect to father child after age 40; research into male fertility described; drawings (M)
